docs.lead_paragraph: New York State's highest court stepped into the legal quagmire of biomedical ethics today, ruling that a woman could not use her frozen embryos to impregnate herself without the consent of her former husband. In a unanimous ruling, the Court of Appeals rejected a lower court's decision that the 40-year-old woman should enjoy the same right to determine the fate of her embryo that a pregnant woman has under the landmark Roe v. Wade decision that upheld a woman's right to determine the fate of her ''nonviable'' fetus.

headline.main: Court Blocks Use of Embryos Without Ex-Husband's Consent

docs.abstract: New York State Court of Appeals rules that Maureen Kass cannot use her frozen embryos to impregnate herself without consent of her former husband Steven; rules that she must abide by contract that they signed before their divorce in 1993 that requires consent of both of them before five embryos can be used (M)
